Κακία or malice, as some will have it, is a general vice, and denotes that vicious propensity which infects all the affections and desires, and inclines them to evil. Whence Bernard, in his Serm. l, De pugn. spir. says, malice is the tastefor evil: it is, then, the property of malice to make evil savoury and sweet3 and, on the contrary, to render good insipid and unpleasant. But in this place I consider κακία to de- note especially that machination of evil in the heart, which is wont to arise from anger in malevolent and incensed minds. We see all these in the example of Cain, Gen. iv. 5, Cain was very wroth and his countenance fell: thence he contrives the murder of Abel, when he says, Let us go out.- This was the effect of his malice.
